body_html:
@rdadolf - thanks for updating to the latest, which eliminates the issue I was commenting on. This might be silly, but have you considered adjusting your PYTHONPATH variable? With that you might be able to get it to find your tensorflow package as well as protobuf. Basically something like this, if import google.protobuf succeeded when you ran python without the path:

PYTHONPATH=$TF_INSTALL_DIR/lib/python2.7/site-packages:$PYTHONPATH python
>>> import tensorflow
...

And, of course, using virtualenv might help (it works great for me), but it looks like you specifically don't want to go that route, since you have it as a submodule. Good luck!

With that you might be able to get it to find your tensorflow package as well as protobuf. Basically something like this, if import google.protobuf succeeded when you ran python without the path:
PYTHONPATH=$TF_INSTALL_DIR/lib/python2.7/site-packages:$PYTHONPATH python

body:
@rdadolf - thanks for updating to the latest, which eliminates the issue I was commenting on. This might be silly, but have you considered adjusting your `PYTHONPATH` variable? With that you might be able to get it to find your tensorflow package as well as protobuf. Basically something like this, if `import google.protobuf` succeeded when you ran `python` without the path:

```
PYTHONPATH=$TF_INSTALL_DIR/lib/python2.7/site-packages:$PYTHONPATH python
>>> import tensorflow
...
```

And, of course, using virtualenv might help (it works great for me), but it looks like you specifically don't want to go that route, since you have it as a submodule. Good luck!
